Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Linking shifts in microbial community composition and N cycling to multiple global change factors in a California grassland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human-induced changes in the environment have the ability to alter soil nutrient cycles, thereby affecting the many ecosystem services on which humans rely. However, despite the fact that these changes often occur simultaneously, few studies have investigated their interactive effects on the important belowground components of an ecosystem. Because nitrogen (N) is the limiting nutrient for plant growth in most terrestrial systems, it is essential to understand how N cycling responds to both biotic and abiotic changes. This project will contribute to global change ecology by assessing how soil microorganisms that mediate N cycling respond to the interaction of three primary changes in the environment: elevated N deposition, cattle grazing, and invasive plants. Soil has been sampled from beneath plant communities that were subjected to simulated N deposition, cattle grazing and experienced the invasion of an exotic plant species. Microbial DNA will be extracted from the soil to understand how N-cycling microorganisms respond to the treatments. Changes in the microbial community will then be related to changes in N cycling processes. Results from this project will contribute new insight into community level changes in microorganisms that are responsible for key steps in the N cycle, ultimately helping to advance current knowledge of nutrient dynamics in terrestrial ecosystems.

Project results will be presented at national and international conferences, such as the International Society of Microbial Ecology, in order to ensure widespread dissemination across the scientific community. Workforce development will occur through the training of two undergraduates by their full participation in the research project. Additionally, the results will be published in peer-reviewed journals and findings will be presented to the local community via seminars. Because the University of California, Merced, is located in the Central Valley, a large proportion of the students who receive outreach will be from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human-induced changes in the environment have the ability to alter soil microbial communities and nutrient availability, thereby affecting many ecosystem services on which humans rely. However, despite the fact that these changes often occur simultaneously, few studies have investigated their interactive effects on the belowground components of an ecosystem. Soil microorganisms mediate nutrient cycling, influence plant growth and community composition, and produce and consume greenhouse gases; as such, it is essential to understand how microorganisms respond to both biotic and abiotic changes, and how microbial community composition relates to microbial functioning (e.g., cycling of nitrogen, a nutrient that limits the productivity of most terrestrial ecosystems).

This project assessed how soil microorganisms respond to the interaction of three primary changes in the environment: invasive plants, aboveground vegetation removal, and elevated nitrogen deposition. Soil was sampled from beneath experimental plant communities, some of which were subjected to aboveground clipping of vegetation (to simulate cattle grazing or mowing) and N fertilization (to simulate increased atmospheric deposition from fossil fuel combustion). Microbial DNA was subsequently extracted from the soil and used to quantify how soil microorganisms responded to the treatments. Characterization of bacteria, archaea, and fungi using deep sequencing techniques occurred once, in the spring. Characterization of nitrifying microbial abundance and activity occurred seasonally (over one year) in order to determine whether the influence of treatment was dependent upon time.

Despite observing shifts in microbial functioning with each environmental change, we found that microbial community composition remained stable, showing very little variation across treatments. Nitrifying microbial abundance, however, did change seasonally. These results counter the hypothesis that microbial community composition and diversity will respond strongly to global and regional environmental changes, and provide evidence that microbial functioning can be decoupled from composition.

A major portion of this research has been published in an open access journal (Frontiers in Microbiology), and the other portion is currently being prepared as a second manuscript. Results have been disseminated to a wide-ranging audience, including the academic community (at conferences such as American Geophysical Union Meeting and International Symposium on Microbial Ecology), high school AP science students (in the Central Valley, CA), and the local public (Science Café in the Central Valley, CA).
